717845f-b.text:
(1)
Broome Street, north side, east from but not including Willett, to but not including Sheriff Streets. Also shown is Sheriff Street, east side, north from but not including Broome, to but not including Delancey Streets, as seen through clearance on the former site of Public School No. 34. The view shows the demolition of the rear unit of the R. Hoe and
Company Plant.
June 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a different angle, and showing Sheriff Street, west
side, north from Broome, to and including Delancey Streets.
June 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, as seen across the clearance on the former site of the other annex building, seen under demolition in View No. 1. Also shown is a portion of the Williamsburg Bridge (otherwise known as the..East River Bridge) on Delancey Street and a 1-story public comfort station directly
underneath.
October 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
717845f-b.folder: Broome Street & Willet Street, Manhattan, NY

717846f-a.text:
Broome Street, west from Willet Street. In the right center appears the Seventh Presbyterian Church at the N.E. corner of Ridge
Street.
May 7, 1939
P. L. Sperr
717846f-a.folder: Broome Street & Willet Street, Manhattan, NY

717847f-b.text:
Broome Street, south side, east from Willett Street.
October 12, 1931
L. Sperr
(2)
The same location several years later. Note the trees where the open area appears in View 1. This was developed as a playground-park to form a visita to the Consolidated Apartrents
(modern building shown).
Formerly located here were P. S. No. 34 and a unit of the R. Hoe & Co. plant. In the background, across the roofs of tenements on Columbia Street is the Manhattan support of the Williamsburg Bridge. To the right appears a glimpse of the East Niver and
its Brooklyn shore.
May 7, 1939
P. L. Sperr
717847f-b.folder: Broome Street & Willet Street, Manhattan, NY

717848f-b.text:
(1)
Broome Street, numthzEide, east from Willett Street. Public School No. 34 is the third building from the left.
June 6, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from and including Willett Street, a year later,
showing the school being demolished.
June 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
